searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: The EVM plugin provides comprehensive functionality for interacting with EVM-compatible chains, including token transfers, cross-chain bridging, and token swaps using LiFi integration.

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Multi-chain support with dynamic chain configurationNative token transfersCross-chain token bridging via LiFiToken swapping on supported DEXsWallet balance trackingCustom RPC endpoint configurationAutomatic retry mechanismsComprehensive transaction management

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install @elizaos/plugin-evm

searchDocs.title: Required Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: # Required EVM_PRIVATE_KEY=your-private-key-here # Optional - Custom RPC URLs EVM_PROVIDER_URL=https://your-custom-mainnet-rpc-url ETHEREUM_PROVIDER_<CHAIN_NAME>=https://your-custom-rpc-url

searchDocs.title: Chain Configuration​
searchDocs.content: By default, Ethereum mainnet is enabled. To enable additional chains, add them to your character config:  "settings": { "chains": { "evm": [ "base", "arbitrum", "iotex" ] } }   Note: The chain names must match those in the viem/chains.

searchDocs.title: Custom RPC URLs​
searchDocs.content: By default, the RPC URL is inferred from the viem/chains config. To use a custom RPC URL for a specific chain, add the following to your .env file:  ETHEREUM_PROVIDER_<CHAIN_NAME>=https://your-custom-rpc-url   Example usage:  ETHEREUM_PROVIDER_IOTEX=https://iotex-network.rpc.thirdweb.com   Custom RPC for Ethereum Mainnet​  To set a custom RPC URL for Ethereum mainnet, use:  EVM_PROVIDER_URL=https://your-custom-mainnet-rpc-url

searchDocs.title: Provider​
searchDocs.content: The Wallet Provider initializes with the first chain in the list as the default (or Ethereum mainnet if none are added). It:  Provides the context of the currently connected address and its balance.Creates Public and Wallet clients to interact with the supported chains.Allows adding chains dynamically at runtime.

searchDocs.content: Transfer native tokens on the same chain:  // Example: Transfer 1 ETH Transfer 1 ETH to 0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: The FerePro plugin enables real-time communication with the FerePro API through WebSocket connections, providing market analysis, cryptocurrency comparisons, and financial insights.

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Real-time WebSocket communicationStreaming and non-streaming response supportMarket data analysis and comparisonsCryptocurrency insightsDebug mode for detailed responsesAutomatic connection managementComprehensive error handlingCredit tracking and management

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install @elizaos/plugin-ferepro

searchDocs.title: Required Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: # Required Ensure that FEREAI_USER_ID and FEREAI_API_KEY are correctly set in the character secrets sections or as environment variables. FEREAI_USER_ID: FereAI User ID FEREAI_API_KEY: FereAI API key # Optional FereAI pro take some time to respond. Set REQUEST_TIMEOUT to avoid response timeouts in the character settings section or as environment variable. REQUEST_TIMEOUT: Number of milliseconds before a request times out

searchDocs.title: Example Queries​
searchDocs.content: Basic Market Query:  // Get top cryptocurrencies 'What are the top 5 cryptocurrencies?';   Comparison Analysis:  // Compare specific cryptocurrencies 'Compare Ethereum and Bitcoin for the past 6 months';   Historical Data:  // Get historical performance 'Compare top 3 coins against Bitcoin in the last 3 months';

searchDocs.title: Core Components​
searchDocs.content: FereProService Manages WebSocket connectionsHandles message sending/receivingProcesses streaming responsesTracks credits and usage Actions EXECUTE_FEREPRO: Primary action for API communicationSupports market queries and analysis requestsHandles both streaming and non-streaming responses

searchDocs.title: Response Structure​
searchDocs.content: export interface FereAIChatResponse { answer: string; chat_id: string; representation: any[]; agent_api_name: string; query_summary: string; agent_credits: number; credits_available: number; }

searchDocs.title: Error Handling​
searchDocs.content: The plugin includes comprehensive error handling for:  WebSocket connection issuesInvalid message formatsAPI response errorsCredit limitation issues

searchDocs.title: Connection Issues​
searchDocs.content: WebSocket Connection Failures Verify your internet connectionCheck if the FerePro API service is availableEnsure your FERE_USER_ID and FERE_API_KEY is valid and active Message Timeout The connection might time out for long-running queriesConsider setting REQUEST_TIMEOUT to avoid response timeouts in the character settings section or as environment variable. Credit Depletion Monitor credits_available in responsesSet up alerts for low credit situationsContact FerePro support for credit top-up

searchDocs.title: Response Parsing​
searchDocs.content: Invalid Response Format Check if the query is properly formattedVerify the message structure matches the API requirementsEnable debug mode for detailed error information Missing Data Ensure the requested timeframe is validVerify the cryptocurrencies exist in the databaseCheck if you have access to the requested data tier

searchDocs.title: Security​
searchDocs.content: API Credentials Never expose your FEREAI_USER_ID and FEREAI_API_KEY in public repositoriesUse environment variables or secrets sections in the character settings section for sensitive dataRotate credentials periodically if possible Rate Limiting Implement appropriate delays between requestsMonitor credit usage to prevent unexpected depletionCache responses when appropriate

searchDocs.title: Data Handling​
searchDocs.content: Response Validation Always validate response data before processingImplement proper error handling for malformed dataLog unexpected response formats for debugging Stream Management Close WebSocket connections properly after useImplement reconnection logic for dropped connectionsHandle partial responses in streaming mode

searchDocs.title: Best Practices​
searchDocs.content: Query Optimization Keep queries focused and specificUse streaming for large data requestsImplement caching for frequently requested data Error Handling Implement comprehensive error catchingLog errors with appropriate contextProvide meaningful error messages to users Resource Management Monitor WebSocket connection statusImplement connection pooling for high-volume usageClean up resources properly on service shutdown

searchDocs.content: This plugin is part of the Eliza project. See the main project repository for license information.

searchDocs.title: Core Features​
searchDocs.content: Service Factory Creates a service instance using an API keyReturns an object with two methods: getScrapeData and getCrawlData Web Scraping (getScrapeData) Fetches and extracts content from a single webpageReturns structured data including page content and metadataEndpoint: https://api.firecrawl.dev/v1/scrape Web Searching (getSearchData) Searches for data based on conversationsEndpoint: https://api.firecrawl.dev/v1/search

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: The plugin requires minimal configuration. In your character file, simply add:  { "FIRECRAWL_API_KEY": "your-api-key-here" }

searchDocs.title: Web Scraping​
searchDocs.content: The plugin recognizes various ways users might request web scraping:  // Single URL request 'Can you scrape the content from https://example.com?'; 'Get the data from www.example.com/page'; // Two-step interaction User: 'I need to scrape some website data.'; Agent: "I can help you scrape website data. Please share the URL you'd like me to process."; User: 'example.com/products';

searchDocs.title: Web Search​
searchDocs.content: The plugin handles different crawling request patterns:  // Direct search 'Find the latest news about SpaceX launches'; 'Can you find details about the iPhone 16 release?';

searchDocs.title: Response Handling​
searchDocs.content: The plugin automatically:  Validates URLs before processingHandles both direct and conversational requestsProvides appropriate feedback during the scraping/crawling processReturns structured data from the target website

searchDocs.title: Error Handling​
searchDocs.content: The plugin includes built-in error handling for common scenarios:  Invalid or missing URLsAPI authentication issuesNetwork failuresMalformed responses

searchDocs.title: Actions​
searchDocs.content: The plugin provides two main actions:  FIRECRAWL_GET_SCRAPED_DATA: For single-page content extractionWEB_SEARCH: Web search for any data

searchDocs.title: Security​
searchDocs.content: API keys should be kept secure and never sharedAll requests are made over HTTPSInput validation is performed on all URLs before processing

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: This plugin provides essential functionality for interacting with the Flow blockchain, including native FLOW token transfers, fungible token transfers, and EVM token interactions. It offers a seamless way to manage Flow blockchain transactions through natural language commands.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install @elizaos/plugin-flow

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: The plugin requires the following environment variables to be set:  FLOW_ADDRESS=<Flow wallet address starting with 0x> FLOW_PRIVATE_KEY=<Private key for the Flow wallet starting with 0x> FLOW_NETWORK=<Network to connect to: "mainnet", "testnet", or "emulator" (optional, defaults to "mainnet")> FLOW_ENDPOINT_URL=<Custom RPC endpoint URL (optional)>

searchDocs.title: Basic Integration​
searchDocs.content: import { flowPlugin } from '@elizaos/plugin-flow';

searchDocs.title: Example Usage​
searchDocs.content: The plugin supports natural language commands for token transfers:  'Send 5 FLOW to 0xa51d7fe9e0080662'; 'Send 1 FLOW - A.1654653399040a61.FlowToken to 0xa2de93114bae3e73'; 'Send 1000 FROTH - 0xb73bf8e6a4477a952e0338e6cc00cc0ce5ad04ba to 0x000000000000000000000002e44fbfbd00395de5';

searchDocs.title: Actions​
searchDocs.content: SEND_COIN​  Transfers native FLOW tokens, Cadence fungible tokens, or EVM tokens to specified addresses.  Aliases:  SEND_TOKENSEND_TOKEN_ON_FLOWTRANSFER_TOKEN_ON_FLOWTRANSFER_TOKENS_ON_FLOWTRANSFER_FLOWSEND_FLOWPAY_BY_FLOW  Input Content:  interface TransferContent { token: string | null; // null for native FLOW, Cadence identifier, or EVM address amount: string; // Amount to transfer to: string; // Recipient address (Flow or EVM) matched: boolean; // Indicates if token and address types match }

searchDocs.title: Common Issues & Troubleshooting​
searchDocs.content: Connection Issues Verify network configuration (mainnet/testnet/emulator)Check RPC endpoint availabilityEnsure proper wallet configuration Transaction Failures Verify sufficient balance for transfersCheck correct address format (Flow vs EVM)Confirm token contract compatibility Authentication Issues Validate private key formatVerify wallet address matches private keyCheck network permissions

searchDocs.title: Security Best Practices​
searchDocs.content: Key Management Store private keys securelyUse environment variables for sensitive dataNever expose private keys in code or logs Transaction Safety Validate all addresses before transfersImplement proper error handlingCheck token compatibility before transfers

searchDocs.title: Setting Up Development Environment​
searchDocs.content: Clone the repositoryInstall dependencies:  bun install   Build the plugin:  bun run build   Run tests:  bun run test

searchDocs.title: Future Enhancements​
searchDocs.content: Support for NFT transfersEnhanced error handling and recoveryAdditional Flow blockchain interactionsExpanded token support

searchDocs.content: Contributions are welcome! Please see the CONTRIBUTING.md file for more information.

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: The Football plugin integrates with the Football-Data.org API to enable ElizaOS agents to fetch live football match information and league standings. It includes actions and utilities to provide real-time football data in conversations.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: To install the plugin, use the following command:  bun install @elizaos/plugin-football

searchDocs.title: 1. Live Match Data​
searchDocs.content: Action: fetchMatchAction Retrieves live football match data, including: TeamsScoresGame events Provides real-time updates for ongoing matches.

searchDocs.title: 2. League Standings​
searchDocs.content: Action: fetchStandingsAction Fetches league standings for a specified competition, including: Team rankingsPointsGoals scoredOther league statistics.

searchDocs.title: 3. Flexible Integration​
searchDocs.content: Extendable for additional football data, such as: Player statisticsMatch schedulesHistorical match data.

searchDocs.title: API Key Configuration​
searchDocs.content: To use this plugin, you need an API key from Football-Data.org.  Register and obtain your API key from Football-Data.org. Add the API key to your .env file: FOOTBALL_API_KEY=your_api_key_here   The plugin will use this key to authenticate requests.

searchDocs.title: fetchMatchAction​
searchDocs.content: Description: Retrieves live match data.  Code Example:  import { fetchMatchAction } from '@elizaos/plugin-football'; const result = await fetchMatchAction.handler(runtime, message, state); console.log(result);   Sample Output:  { "matches": [ { "homeTeam": { "name": "Chelsea" }, "awayTeam": { "name": "Arsenal" }, "score": { "fullTime": { "homeTeam": 1, "awayTeam": 2 } } } ] }

searchDocs.title: fetchStandingsAction​
searchDocs.content: Description: Fetches league standings for a specific competition.  Code Example:  import { fetchStandingsAction } from '@elizaos/plugin-football'; const result = await fetchStandingsAction.handler(runtime, message, state); console.log(result);   Sample Output:  { "standings": [ { "table": [ { "position": 1, "team": { "name": "Manchester City" }, "points": 45 }, { "position": 2, "team": { "name": "Arsenal" }, "points": 42 } ] } ] }

searchDocs.title: Steps to Build and Test​
searchDocs.content: Clone the repository: git clone https://github.com/elizaOS/eliza.git Navigate to the plugin-football directory and install dependencies: cd packages/plugin-football bun install Build the plugin: bun run build Run linting: bun run lint Test the plugin: bun vitest src/tests/match-action.test.ts bun vitest src/tests/fetch-standings-action.test.ts

searchDocs.content: This plugin relies on the following dependency:  @elizaos/core: workspace:*

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: Form Chain is a blockchain platform that implements curves-based token economics, allowing users to interact with bonding curves for token creation, trading, and management. This plugin integrates Form chain with Eliza, giving your agent the ability to:  Buy and sell curves tokensConvert between curves and ERC20 tokensManage token holdingsQuery prices and balancesCreate new ERC20 tokens for curves  The plugin supports both QUADRATIC and LOGRITHMIC formulas, optimizing for different use cases and trading volumes.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install @elizaos/plugin-form

searchDocs.title: Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: FORM_PRIVATE_KEY=<Your Form chain wallet private key> FORM_TESTNET=true # Optional, defaults to false

searchDocs.title: Plugin Setup​
searchDocs.content: // In your agent configuration import { formPlugin } from '@elizaos/plugin-form'; const character = { plugins: [formPlugin], // ... other configuration };

searchDocs.title: BUY_CURVES_TOKEN​
searchDocs.content: Buy curves tokens for a subject address.  await runtime.processAction('BUY_CURVES_TOKEN', { subject: '0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e', amount: 1, formula: 'QUADRATIC', // or "LOGRITHMIC" for high volume });

searchDocs.title: SELL_CURVES_TOKEN​
searchDocs.content: Sell curves tokens back to the protocol.  await runtime.processAction('SELL_CURVES_TOKEN', { subject: '0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e', amount: 1, formula: 'QUADRATIC', });

searchDocs.title: WITHDRAW_CURVES_TOKEN​
searchDocs.content: Convert curves tokens to their ERC20 equivalent.  await runtime.processAction('WITHDRAW_CURVES_TOKEN', { subject: '0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e', amount: 1, formula: 'QUADRATIC', });

searchDocs.title: DEPOSIT_CURVES_TOKEN​
searchDocs.content: Convert ERC20 tokens back to curves.  await runtime.processAction('DEPOSIT_CURVES_TOKEN', { subject: '0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e', amount: '1000000000000000000', // 1 token in 18 decimals formula: 'QUADRATIC', });

searchDocs.title: MINT_CURVES_ERC20​
searchDocs.content: Mint new ERC20 token for curves holdings.  await runtime.processAction('MINT_CURVES_ERC20', { name: 'My Token', symbol: 'MTK', formula: 'QUADRATIC', });

searchDocs.title: GET_CURVES_BALANCE​
searchDocs.content: Check curves token balance.  await runtime.processAction('GET_CURVES_BALANCE', { subject: '0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e', formula: 'QUADRATIC', });

searchDocs.title: GET_CURVES_BUY_PRICE​
searchDocs.content: Get price quote for buying curves.  await runtime.processAction('GET_CURVES_BUY_PRICE', { subject: '0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e', amount: 1, formula: 'QUADRATIC', });

searchDocs.title: GET_CURVES_SELL_PRICE​
searchDocs.content: Get price quote for selling curves.  await runtime.processAction('GET_CURVES_SELL_PRICE', { subject: '0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e', amount: 1, formula: 'QUADRATIC', });

searchDocs.title: Formula Selection​
searchDocs.content: The plugin supports two bonding curve formulas:

searchDocs.title: QUADRATIC​
searchDocs.content: Default formula for standard operationsSuitable for personal and small group usageBalanced price impact

searchDocs.title: LOGRITHMIC​
searchDocs.content: Optimized for high volume tradingBetter price stabilityRecommended for large-scale operations

searchDocs.title: Security​
searchDocs.content: Store private keys securely using environment variablesNever expose keys in code or commitsValidate addresses before transactionsCheck balances before operations

searchDocs.title: Performance​
searchDocs.content: Use caching for repeated price checks  Trading  Always check price quotes before tradingUse appropriate formula for volumeMonitor price impact

searchDocs.title: Error Handling​
searchDocs.content: The plugin provides detailed error messages for common issues:  try { await runtime.processAction("BUY_CURVES_TOKEN", {...}); } catch (error) { if (error.message.includes("insufficient balance")) { // Handle insufficient funds } else if (error.message.includes("price impact too high")) { // Handle excessive price impact } }

searchDocs.title: Actions​

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Sponsored Calls: Interact with contracts without needing gas on the user's side.ERC2771 Support: Execute meta-transactions via Gelato's sponsoredCallERC2771.Customizable: Easily configure chains, contracts, and user-specific settings.

searchDocs.title: Prerequisites​
searchDocs.content: bunA Gelato Relay API key

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install elizaos/plugin-gelato

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: Fill out the .env file in the project root with the following variables:  GELATO_RELAY_API_KEY=<Your Gelato Relay API Key> EVM_PROVIDER_URL=<Your EVM provider URL (e.g., Alchemy or Infura endpoint)> EVM_PRIVATE_KEY=<Your wallet's private key>

searchDocs.title: For Non-ERC2771 (Standard Sponsored Call)​
searchDocs.content: Call increment() on 0x3890DB55ff538FBF281c9152820A4a748f5D6F21 contract: - Function Name: increment - Args: [] - Target: 0x3890DB55ff538FBF281c9152820A4a748f5D6F21 - Chain: arbitrumSepolia - ABI: ["function increment()"]

searchDocs.title: For ERC2771 (Meta-Transactions)​
searchDocs.content: Call increment() on 0x00172f67db60E5fA346e599cdE675f0ca213b47b contract: - Function Name: increment - Args: [] - Target: 0x00172f67db60E5fA346e599cdE675f0ca213b47b - Chain: arbitrumSepolia - ABI: ["function increment()"] - User: 0xYourAddressHere

searchDocs.title: Example Output​
searchDocs.content: For both scenarios, successful execution returns:  ✅ Contract interaction successful! - Function: increment - Target: 0x<contract_address> - Chain: arbitrumSepolia - Task ID: <task_id> - Track Status: [View Task](https://relay.gelato.digital/tasks/status/<task_id>)

searchDocs.title: Code Structure​
searchDocs.content: utils.ts: Contains functions for sponsoredCall and sponsoredCallERC2771. schemas.ts: Defines Zod schemas to validate user input. actions.ts: Contains the action logic, including parsing natural language input and invoking Gelato Relay.

searchDocs.title: Testing​
searchDocs.content: Update your .env file with valid keys.Test both ERC2771 and non-ERC2771 prompts using the examples above.

searchDocs.title: Troubleshooting​
searchDocs.content: Ensure your .env file is properly configured.Verify that your contract ABI, function name, and chain match the deployed contract details.For ERC2771 calls, confirm the User address is correct and matches the expected _msgSender logic in the contract.

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Task automation and managementInteraction handling with GigBot APIToken earning through task completionsApproval workflow via Discord (optional)

searchDocs.title: Prerequisites​
searchDocs.content: Node.js and bun installedEliza runtime

searchDocs.title: Step 1: Configure Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: Create or edit .env file in your project root:  # GigBot API Credentials GIGBOT_API_URL=https://www.gigbot.xyz/api # Default API URL for GigBot # Client Configuration GIG_SEARCH_INTERVAL=3 # Interval for searching tasks (hours) GIG_ACTION_INTERVAL=12 # Interval for performing actions (hours) GIG_CLAIM_INTERVAL=24 # Interval for claiming tasks (hours) GIG_CLAIM_PLATFORM=x # Platform for claiming tasks ('x' or 'farcaster') EVM_PRIVATE_KEY=0x... # Private key for claiming rewards (must start with 0x)

searchDocs.title: Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: Variable	Description	Default	RequiredGIGBOT_API_URL	GigBot API endpoint	https://www.gigbot.xyz/api	No GIG_SEARCH_INTERVAL	How often to search for new tasks (hours)	3	No GIG_ACTION_INTERVAL	How often to perform task actions (hours)	12	No GIG_CLAIM_INTERVAL	How often to claim completed tasks (hours)	24	No GIG_CLAIM_PLATFORM	Platform to claim tasks from ('x' or 'farcaster')	x	No EVM_PRIVATE_KEY	Ethereum private key for claiming rewards	-	Yes  Important Security Note:  Keep your EVM_PRIVATE_KEY secure and never commit it to version controlUse a dedicated wallet for the agent with limited fundsConsider using environment variables or a secure secret management system

searchDocs.title: Step 2: Initialize the Client​
searchDocs.content: import { GigBotClientInterface } from '@elizaos/gigbot'; const gigbotPlugin = { name: 'gigbot', description: 'GigBot client', clients: [GigBotClientInterface], }; // Register with your Eliza runtime runtime.registerPlugin(gigbotPlugin);   Important: The GigBot plugin requires the Twitter client to be initialized first. You must:  Include the Twitter plugin before GigBot in your plugins arrayModify the client initialization to pass existing clients to GigBot  Example of required client initialization:  export async function initializeClients(character: Character, runtime: IAgentRuntime) { const clients: ClientInstance[] = []; if (character.plugins?.length > 0) { for (const plugin of character.plugins) { // Check if current plugin is GigBot let isGigbot = plugin.name === '@elizaos-plugins/plugin-gigbot'; if (plugin.clients) { for (const client of plugin.clients) { // Pass existing clients to GigBot runtime const startedClient = await client.start(isGigbot ? { ...runtime, clients } : runtime); clients.push(startedClient); } } } } return clients; }

searchDocs.title: Task Automation​
searchDocs.content: The client can automatically complete tasks based on your agent's capabilities and GigBot's available tasks. Tasks can be:  Simple tasksComplex workflowsToken-earning opportunities

searchDocs.title: Interactions​
searchDocs.content: Handles:  Task collectionTask completionReward claiming

searchDocs.title: Testing​
searchDocs.content: # Run tests bun test # Run with debug logging DEBUG=eliza:* bun start

searchDocs.title: Common Issues​
searchDocs.content: API Failures​  Verify credentials in .envCheck API configuration

searchDocs.title: Security Notes​
searchDocs.content: Never commit .env or credential filesUse environment variables for sensitive dataImplement proper rate limitingMonitor API usage and costs

searchDocs.title: Support​
searchDocs.content: For issues or questions:  Check the Common Issues sectionReview debug logs (enable with DEBUG=eliza:*)Open an issue with: Error messagesConfiguration detailsSteps to reproduce

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: The Plugin Giphy enhances your agent's interactions by enabling it to respond with relevant GIFs based on user inputs. Leveraging the Giphy API, this plugin detects specific triggers in user messages and responds with appropriate GIFs to make conversations more engaging and expressive.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun add @elizaos/plugin-giphy

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: Set up your environment with the required Giphy API key:  Variable Name	DescriptionGIPHY_API_KEY	Giphy API key for authenticating requests  You need to obtain an API key by signing up at Giphy Developers.

searchDocs.title: Usage​
searchDocs.content: import { giphyPlugin } from '@elizaos/plugin-giphy'; // Initialize the plugin const plugin = giphyPlugin; // Add the plugin to your agent's plugin list const plugins = [ giphyPlugin, // ... other plugins ]; // Initialize your agent with the plugins // Example: // const agent = new Agent({ plugins, ...otherConfig });   The plugin provides the SEND_GIF action, which automatically responds with a GIF based on the context of user messages. No additional setup is required beyond installing and configuring the plugin.

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: This plugin enables seamless integration with GitBook documentation, allowing natural language queries to retrieve relevant documentation content. It features intelligent query validation, keyword-based filtering, and clean response formatting to provide accurate documentation answers.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install @elizaos/plugin-gitbook

searchDocs.title: Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: GITBOOK_SPACE_ID=<Your GitBook Space ID>

searchDocs.title: Client Configuration (Optional)​
searchDocs.content: You can customize the plugin's behavior by adding the following configuration to your character.json file:  { "name": "YourCharacter", "plugins": ["gitbook"], "settings": { "gitbook": { "keywords": { "projectTerms": ["term1", "term2"], // Optional: Project-specific terms to match "generalQueries": ["custom1", "custom2"] // Optional: Additional query keywords }, "documentTriggers": ["docs", "documentation"] // Optional: Trigger words for documentation } } }   The plugin will work with default settings if no configuration is provided, but adding custom configuration can help tailor the responses to your specific documentation needs.

searchDocs.title: Basic Integration​
searchDocs.content: import { gitbookPlugin } from '@elizaos/plugin-gitbook';

searchDocs.title: Example Usage​
searchDocs.content: The plugin automatically processes natural language queries:  'How do I get started with the project?'; 'What are the main features?'; 'Explain how to configure the system';

searchDocs.title: Providers​
searchDocs.content: GitBook Provider​  Handles documentation queries and returns relevant information.  Response Type:  interface GitBookResponse { answer?: { text: string; }; error?: string; }   Configuration Types:  interface GitBookKeywords { projectTerms?: string[]; // Project-specific terms generalQueries?: string[]; // Additional query keywords } interface GitBookClientConfig { keywords?: GitBookKeywords; documentTriggers?: string[]; // Trigger words for documentation }

searchDocs.content: Connection Issues Verify GitBook Space ID is correctCheck API endpoint accessibilityEnsure proper network connectivity Query Issues Verify query contains valid keywordsCheck if query matches project termsEnsure proper query formatting Response Issues Validate GitBook API response formatCheck for rate limitingVerify content accessibility

searchDocs.content: API Configuration Store Space ID securelyUse environment variablesImplement proper error handling Query Validation Sanitize input queriesValidate keywords and triggersClean response content Response Handling Implement proper error handlingValidate response formatHandle sensitive information appropriately

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: Just add it under your character profile in plugins as   "plugins": [ "@elizaos/plugin-gitcoin-passport" ],

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: Getting Your API Key  Log in to the developer portal: Go to developer.passport.xyz and log in to your account by connecting your wallet.Navigate to the API Keys section: After logging in, go to the "API Keys" section.Generate an API key: Click on the "+ Create a Key" button to generate a unique API key for your account.Store your API key securely: Store your API key in a secure place, as it will be used to access the Passport API.  Getting your Scorer ID  Log in to the Developer Portal: Go to developer.passport.xyz and log in to your account by connecting your wallet.Navigate to the Scorer section: After logging in, go to the "Scorer" sectionCreate a Scorer: Click on the "+ Create a Scorer" button and input a Scorer name and description. Make sure you use the Unique Humanity scorer, and not the Binary scorer.Find your Scorer ID: Click on the newly created Scorer and you will see the Scorer ID in the page URL. Example: https://developer.passport.xyz/dashboard/scorer/{scorer_id}

searchDocs.title: Usage​
searchDocs.content: Results are saved as message and agents can retrive it from there for different use cases. Default passport treshold of 20 is used, but you can pick your own value and match it agains that

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: GOAT 🐐 (Great Onchain Agent Toolkit) is an open-source framework for adding blockchain tools such as wallets, being able to hold or trade tokens, or interacting with blockchain smart contracts, to your AI agent.  Chains supportedPlugins supported  This plugin integrates GOAT with Eliza, giving your agent the ability to interact with many different protocols. The current setup adds onchain capabilities to your agent to send and check balances of ETH and USDC, and to swap tokens using KIM protocol. Add all the capabilities you need by adding more plugins (read below for more information)!

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install @elizaos/plugin-goat

searchDocs.title: Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: EVM_PRIVATE_KEY=<Your EVM wallet private key> EVM_PROVIDER_URL=<Your RPC provider URL (e.g., Infura, Alchemy)>

searchDocs.title: Configure GOAT for your use case​
searchDocs.content: Configure the chain you want to use by updating the wallet.ts file (see all available chains at https://ohmygoat.dev/chains)Specify the actions you want to have by updating the actions.ts fileAdd the plugins you need to perform these actions to the getOnChainTools function (uniswap, polymarket, etc. see all available plugins at https://ohmygoat.dev/chains-wallets-plugins)Build the project running bun buildAdd the necessary environment variables to set up your wallet and pluginsRun your agent!

searchDocs.title: Common Issues​
searchDocs.content: Agent not executing an action: If you are also using the EVM Plugin, sometimes the agent might confuse the action name with an EVM Plugin action name instead of the GOAT Plugin action. Removing the EVM Plugin should fix this issue. There is no need for you to use both plugins at the same time.If you are using Trump as a character it might be tricky to get them to perform any action since the character is full of prompts that aim to change the topic of the conversation. To fix this try using a different character or create your own with prompts that are more suitable to what the agent is supposed to do.

searchDocs.title: Plugins​
searchDocs.content: GOAT itself has several plugins for interacting with different protocols such as Polymarket, Uniswap, and many more. (see all available plugins at https://ohmygoat.dev/chains-wallets-plugins)  You can easily add them by installing them and adding them to the getOnChainActions function:  const tools = getOnChainActions({ wallet: walletClient, plugins: [ sendETH(), erc20({ tokens: [USDC, PEPE] }), polymarket(), uniswap(), // ... ], });   See all available plugins at https://ohmygoat.dev/chains-wallets-plugins

searchDocs.title: Common Issues & Troubleshooting​
searchDocs.content: Agent not executing an action: If you are also using the EVM Plugin, sometimes the agent might confuse the action name with an EVM Plugin action name instead of the GOAT Plugin action. Removing the EVM Plugin should fix this issue. There is no need for you to use both plugins at the same time.If you are using Trump as a character it might be tricky to get them to perform any action since the character is full of prompts that aim to change the topic of the conversation. To fix this try using a different character or create your own with prompts that are more suitable to what the agent is supposed to do. searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: List available GPUs with specifications and pricingCheck account balanceMonitor GPU instance statusView spending historyRent GPU instancesTerminate GPU instances

searchDocs.title: 1. GET_HB_AVAILABLE_GPUS​
searchDocs.content: Lists all available GPU machines on the Hyperbolic platform with their specifications and pricing.  Example prompt:  Show me available GPUs on Hyperbolic

searchDocs.title: 2. GET_CURRENT_BALANCE​
searchDocs.content: Checks your current balance on the Hyperbolic platform.  Example prompt:  Show my current balance on Hyperbolic

searchDocs.title: 3. GET_GPU_STATUS​
searchDocs.content: Monitors the status of all your GPU instances.  Example prompt:  Check status of all my GPU instances on Hyperbolic

searchDocs.title: 4. GET_SPEND_HISTORY​
searchDocs.content: Shows your spending history on the Hyperbolic platform.  Example prompt:  Show my spending history on Hyperbolic

searchDocs.title: 5. RENT_HB_COMPUTE​
searchDocs.content: Rents a GPU instance using node ID and cluster name.  Example prompt:  Create a GPU instance on the Hyperbolic [nodeid]las1-prd-acl-msi-09.fen.intra[/nodeid] [cluster]circular-snapdragon-worm[/cluster]   Required format:  Node ID must be wrapped in [nodeid] tagsCluster name must be wrapped in [cluster] tags

searchDocs.title: 6. TERMINATE_COMPUTE​
searchDocs.content: Terminates a running GPU instance.  Example prompts:  Terminate the Hyperbolic instance [gpu]worse-walnut-viper[/gpu]   Terminate the Hyperbolic instance [gpu]puny-clover-basilisk[/gpu]   Important Note: When terminating an instance, you must provide the instance ID wrapped in [gpu] tags. The examples above show two different instance IDs (worse-walnut-viper and puny-clover-basilisk) to demonstrate the format.

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: The plugin requires the following environment variables:  HYPERBOLIC_API_KEY=your_api_key_here HYPERBOLIC_ENV=production # or development HYPERBOLIC_GRANULAR_LOG=true # optional, for detailed logging HYPERBOLIC_LOG_LEVEL=debug # optional, to control the level HYPERBOLIC_SPASH=true # to show the splash

searchDocs.title: Response Format​
searchDocs.content: All actions return structured responses with:  Success/failure statusDetailed error messages when applicableFormatted text outputAdditional data specific to each action

searchDocs.title: Error Handling​
searchDocs.content: The plugin includes comprehensive error handling for:  Invalid API keysNetwork issuesInvalid input formatsAPI rate limitsServer errors

searchDocs.title: Logging​
searchDocs.content: Granular logging is available by setting HYPERBOLIC_GRANULAR_LOG=true. This provides detailed information about:  API requests and responsesValidation stepsError detailsAction execution flow

searchDocs.title: Development​
searchDocs.content: To extend or modify this plugin:  All actions are in the src/actions directoryUtility functions are in src/utilsEnvironment configuration is in src/environment.tsError types are in src/error/base.ts

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: 💱 Spot Trading Market orders (immediate execution)Limit orders (price-specific)Smart price validation to prevent mistakes 📊 Price Checking Real-time price information24h price changeVolume statistics 🔄 Order Management Cancel all open ordersClear feedback on execution

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: Add the plugin to your Eliza configuration:  { "plugins": ["@elizaos/plugin-hyperliquid"] }

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: Set the following environment variables:  HYPERLIQUID_PRIVATE_KEY=your_private_key # Required for trading and cancelling orders HYPERLIQUID_TESTNET=true_or_false # Optional, defaults to false

searchDocs.title: 1. SPOT_TRADE​
searchDocs.content: Place spot market or limit orders.  Examples:  # Market Orders "buy 1 PIP" -> Buys 1 PIP at market price "sell 2 HYPE" -> Sells 2 HYPE at market price "market buy 1 ETH" -> Buys 1 ETH at market price # Limit Orders "buy 1 PIP at 20 USDC" -> Places buy order for 1 PIP at 20 USDC "sell 0.5 HYPE at 21 USDC" -> Places sell order for 0.5 HYPE at 21 USDC

searchDocs.title: 2. PRICE_CHECK​
searchDocs.content: Get current price information for any token.  Examples:  "What's the price of PIP?" "Check HYPE price" "Get ETH price"   Returns: Current price, 24h change, and volume.

searchDocs.title: 3. CANCEL_ORDERS​
searchDocs.content: Cancel all your open orders.  Examples:  "Cancel all orders" "Cancel my orders"

searchDocs.title: Price Validation​
searchDocs.content: The plugin includes smart price validation to prevent mistakes:  Market Orders: Validates price is within ±50% of market priceLimit Orders: Buy orders must be below market priceSell orders must be above market priceWarns if price is very different from market (±80%)

searchDocs.title: Error Handling​
searchDocs.content: The plugin provides clear error messages for common issues:  Invalid token symbolsPrice validation failuresNetwork connection issuesOrder execution failures

searchDocs.title: Security Notes​
searchDocs.content: Store your private key securely using environment variablesTest with small amounts firstUse testnet for initial testingMonitor your orders regularlyDouble-check prices before confirming trades

searchDocs.title: ImageDescriptionService​
searchDocs.content: Processes and analyzes images to generate descriptions. Supports multiple providers:  Local processing using Florence modelOpenAI Vision APIGoogle Gemini  Configuration:  # For OpenAI Vision OPENAI_API_KEY=your_openai_api_key # For Google Gemini GOOGLE_GENERATIVE_AI_API_KEY=your_google_api_key   Provider selection:  If imageVisionModelProvider is set to google/openai, it will use this one.Else if model is set to google/openai, it will use this one.Default if nothing is set is OpenAI.  The service automatically handles different image formats, including GIFs (first frame extraction).  Features by provider:  Local (Florence):  Basic image captioningLocal processing without API calls  OpenAI Vision:  Detailed image descriptionsText detectionObject recognition  Google Gemini 1.5:  High-quality image understandingDetailed descriptions with natural languageMulti-modal context understandingSupport for complex scenes and content  The provider can be configured through the runtime settings, allowing easy switching between providers based on your needs.  // ... existing code ...

searchDocs.title: Module Organization​
searchDocs.content: Each module file follows a consistent organization pattern:

searchDocs.title: 1. File Structure​
searchDocs.content: // src/[module].ts import { createGenericAction } from './base'; import * as ModuleTemplates from '@injective/template/[module]'; import * as ModuleExamples from '@injective/examples/[module]'; // Export individual actions export const Action1 = createGenericAction({...}); export const Action2 = createGenericAction({...}); // Export all actions as a group export const ModuleActions = [ Action1, Action2, // ...other actions ];

searchDocs.title: 2. Main Export File​
searchDocs.content: // src/index.ts export * from './auction'; export * from './auth'; // ...other module exports export const InjectiveActions = [ ...ExchangeActions, ...AuctionActions, // ...other module actions ];

searchDocs.title: auction.ts​
searchDocs.content: Handles auction-related functionality including module parameters, auction rounds, and bidding.

searchDocs.title: auth.ts​
searchDocs.content: Manages authentication, account details, and authorization grants.

searchDocs.title: bank.ts​
searchDocs.content: Handles account balances, token transfers, and supply queries.

searchDocs.title: distribution.ts​
searchDocs.content: Manages reward distribution and withdrawals.

searchDocs.title: exchange.ts​
searchDocs.content: Core exchange functionality including spot/derivative markets, orders, and positions.

searchDocs.title: explorer.ts​
searchDocs.content: Blockchain explorer functionality including transaction and block queries.

searchDocs.title: gov.ts​
searchDocs.content: Handles protocol governance including proposals and voting.

searchDocs.title: ibc.ts​
searchDocs.content: Inter-Blockchain Communication functionality.

searchDocs.title: insurance.ts​
searchDocs.content: Manages insurance funds and redemptions.

searchDocs.title: mint.ts​
searchDocs.content: Controls token minting and inflation parameters.

searchDocs.title: mito.ts​
searchDocs.content: Handles Mito-specific functionality.

searchDocs.title: peggy.ts​
searchDocs.content: Manages Ethereum bridge operations.

searchDocs.title: permissions.ts​
searchDocs.content: Controls role-based access and permissions.

searchDocs.title: staking.ts​
searchDocs.content: Manages validator operations and delegations.

searchDocs.title: token-factory.ts​
searchDocs.content: Handles token creation and management.

searchDocs.title: wasm.ts​
searchDocs.content: Smart contract functionality including deployment and execution.

searchDocs.title: Adding New Actions​
searchDocs.content: Add action to appropriate module file:  export const NewAction = createGenericAction({ name: 'ACTION_NAME', description: 'Action description', template: Templates.template, examples: Examples.example, functionName: 'functionName', validateContent: () => true, }); export const ModuleActions = [...existingActions, NewAction];

searchDocs.title: Adding New Modules​
searchDocs.content: Create new module file:  // src/new-module.ts export const NewModuleActions = [...];   Add to main exports:  // src/index.ts export * from './new-module';

searchDocs.title: Installation​

searchDocs.title: Usage​

searchDocs.content: Feel free to contribute to more similes, examples and refined templates - for a more robust action contorl.  Fork the repositoryCreate your feature branchCommit your changesPush to the branchCreate a Pull Request

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Research question answering with academic citationsRate limit management (10 free requests/day)Automatic reference tracking

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun add @elizaos/plugin-isaacx

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: First, visit isaacx.ai/docs to create your API key. Add your Isaac X API key to your environment variables:  ISAACX_API_KEY=ix_your_api_key_here   Register the plugin in your character configuration:  import isaacXPlugin from '@elizaos/plugin-isaacx'; const character = { plugins: [isaacXPlugin], };

searchDocs.title: Usage​
searchDocs.content: // Ask a research question const response = await runtime.processAction('ANSWER_RESEARCH_QUESTION', { question: 'What are the latest developments in quantum computing?', }); // The response will include both the answer and academic citations console.log('Research Findings:', response.answer); console.log('Academic Sources:', response.references);

searchDocs.title: Response Format​
searchDocs.content: interface IsaacXResponse { answer: string; references: string[]; }

searchDocs.title: Rate Limiting​
searchDocs.content: 10 free requests per day40 $ISAACX per request (~$0.05 USD)20% discount for bulk usage (100+ requests)

searchDocs.title: Development​
searchDocs.content: # Build the plugin bun build # Run tests bun test

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: The Abstract plugin enables seamless token transfers on the Abstract testnet. It provides functionality to transfer both native ETH and ERC20 tokens using secure wallet operations.

searchDocs.title: Installation​

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: The plugin requires the following environment variables to be set:  LENS_ADDRESS=<Your Lens wallet address> LENS_PRIVATE_KEY=<Your Lens private key>

searchDocs.title: Basic Integration​
searchDocs.content: import { lensPlugin } from '@elizaos/plugin-lensNetwork';

searchDocs.title: Transfer Examples​
searchDocs.content: // The plugin responds to natural language commands like: 'Send 1 Grass to 0xCCa8009f5e09F8C5dB63cb0031052F9CB635Af62';

searchDocs.title: Actions​
searchDocs.content: SEND_TOKEN​  Transfers tokens from the agent's wallet to another address.  Aliases:  TRANSFER_TOKEN_ON_LENSTRANSFER_TOKENS_ON_LENSSEND_TOKENS_ON_LENSSEND_ETH_ON_LENSPAY_ON_LENSMOVE_TOKENS_ON_LENSMOVE_ETH_ON_LENS

searchDocs.title: Common Issues & Troubleshooting​

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: The LightLink Plugin allows agents to interact with the LightLink network.

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: The plugin lets agents:  Check balances.Transfer both ERC20 and Eth.Swap (via Elektrik)Search the block explorer for contracts and addresses.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun add @elizaos/plugin-lightlink

searchDocs.title: Required Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: # Required EVM_PRIVATE_KEY=your-private-key-here # Optional - Custom RPC URLs LIGHTLINK_MAINNET_RPC_URL=https://your-custom-mainnet-rpc-url LIGHTLINK_TESTNET_RPC_URL=https://your-custom-testnet-rpc-url

searchDocs.title: Chain Configuration​
searchDocs.content: By default, LightLink Phoenix (mainnet) is enabled. To enable additional chains, add them to your character config:  "settings": { "chains": { "evm": [ "lightlinkTestnet", "ethereum", "sepolia" ] } }

searchDocs.title: Check Balance​
searchDocs.content: Check the balance of an address. All address can be written as an ENS name or a raw address.  // Example: Check balance of 0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e Check the balance of vitalik.eth on lightlink

searchDocs.title: Transfer​
searchDocs.content: Transfer native tokens on the same chain:  // Example: Transfer 1 ETH Transfer 1 ETH to 0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e

searchDocs.title: Swap​
searchDocs.content: Swap tokens on the same chain, you can also provide the address of the tokens you want to swap directly.  // Example: Swap 1 ETH to USDC Swap 1 ETH to USDC on lightlink testnet

searchDocs.title: Search​
searchDocs.content: Search the block explorer for contracts and addresses.  // Example: Search for a contract Whats the contract address for the USDC (sometimes written as USDC.e) token on lightlink?

searchDocs.title: Development​
searchDocs.content: Clone the repositoryInstall dependencies: bun installBuild the plugin: bun run buildRun tests: bun test

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: 💱 Make a new off-chain invoice.📊 Make an off-chain payment.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: Add the plugin to your Eliza configuration:  { "plugins": ["@elizaos/plugin-lightning"] }

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: Set the following environment variables:  LND_TLS_CERT=your_lnnode_tls_cert #Base64 of LND certificate LND_MACAROON=020..... #Base64 encoded admin.macaroon file LND_SOCKET='x.x.x.x:10009'

searchDocs.title: 1. CREATE_INVOICE​
searchDocs.content: Make a new off-chain invoice.  Examples:   "Help me create an invoice for 1000sats" "Create an invoice for 1000sats"   Returns: lnbcrt....

searchDocs.title: 2. PAY_INVOICE​
searchDocs.content: Make an off-chain payment.  Examples:   "Pay invoice "

searchDocs.title: Security Notes​
searchDocs.content: Store your LND_TLS_CERT and LND_MACAROON securely using environment variablesTest with small amounts firstUse regtest for initial testing

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: The Plugin Image Generation offers developers tools to handle image-related operations seamlessly. It supports image creation, manipulation, and integration with storage solutions, making it ideal for applications requiring dynamic image generation.

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Dynamic image generationIntegration with storage solutionsOptimized handling for high-resolution images

searchDocs.title: Installation Instructions​
searchDocs.content: To install the plugin, use the following command:  bun install plugin-image-generation

searchDocs.title: Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: Ensure the following environment variables are set:  Variable Name	DescriptionIMAGE_STORAGE_BUCKET	Name of the storage bucket. STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY	Access key for storage integration. STORAGE_SECRET_KEY	Secret key for storage integration.

searchDocs.title: TypeScript Configuration​
searchDocs.content: The plugin assumes a TypeScript environment. Ensure your tsconfig.json includes the necessary compiler options:  { "compilerOptions": { "module": "ESNext", "target": "ES6", "moduleResolution": "node", "strict": true } }

searchDocs.title: Generate an Image​
searchDocs.content: The main functionality allows generating an image dynamically.  import { generateImage } from 'plugin-image-generation'; const image = await generateImage({ width: 800, height: 600, backgroundColor: '#ffffff', text: 'Hello World', font: 'Arial', }); console.log('Generated Image:', image);

searchDocs.title: Upload to Storage​
searchDocs.content: The plugin supports direct integration with storage solutions for uploading images.  import { uploadImage } from 'plugin-image-generation'; const uploadResult = await uploadImage({ imagePath: 'path/to/image.png', bucketName: 'my-storage-bucket', }); console.log('Image uploaded successfully:', uploadResult);

searchDocs.title: generateImage​
searchDocs.content: Parameters​  width: Width of the image.height: Height of the image.backgroundColor: Background color of the image.text: Text to be displayed on the image.font: Font style for the text.  Returns​  A promise that resolves with the generated image.

searchDocs.title: uploadImage​
searchDocs.content: Parameters​  imagePath: Path to the image file.bucketName: Name of the storage bucket.  Returns​  A promise that resolves with the upload result.

searchDocs.title: Issue: Image Not Generated​
searchDocs.content: Solution: Ensure the input parameters for generateImage are valid and properly formatted.

searchDocs.title: Issue: Upload Fails​
searchDocs.content: Solution: Verify that the storage credentials and bucket name are correctly configured.

searchDocs.title: Issue: Poor Image Quality​
searchDocs.content: Solution: Check the resolution and ensure that high-quality settings are applied during generation.

searchDocs.title: Examples Folder​
searchDocs.content: Include sample projects in the examples/ directory for users to reference.

searchDocs.title: Testing Guide​
searchDocs.content: Run tests using bun test.Ensure integration tests cover all major functionalities.

searchDocs.title: Plugin Development Guide​
searchDocs.content: To extend this plugin, add new image generation or manipulation features in the src/ directory.

searchDocs.title: Security Best Practices​
searchDocs.content: Store access keys securely.Use environment variables for sensitive information.Regularly update dependencies.

searchDocs.title: Performance Optimization Guide​
searchDocs.content: Optimize image generation by reducing redundant processing.Use efficient algorithms for image manipulation.Cache frequently used assets.

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: The LLaMA plugin serves as a foundational component of Eliza OS, providing local LLM capabilities using LLaMA models. It enables efficient and customizable text generation with both CPU and GPU support.

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Local LLM Support: Run LLaMA models locallyGPU Acceleration: CUDA support for faster inferenceFlexible Configuration: Customizable parameters for text generationMessage Queuing: Efficient handling of multiple requestsAutomatic Model Management: Download and verification systems

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: npm install @elizaos/plugin-llama

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: The plugin can be configured through environment variables:

searchDocs.title: Core Settings​
searchDocs.content: LLAMALOCAL_PATH=your_model_storage_path OLLAMA_MODEL=optional_ollama_model_name

searchDocs.title: Usage​
searchDocs.content: import { createLlamaPlugin } from '@elizaos/plugin-llama'; // Initialize the plugin const llamaPlugin = createLlamaPlugin(); // Register with Eliza OS elizaos.registerPlugin(llamaPlugin);

searchDocs.title: LlamaService​
searchDocs.content: Provides local LLM capabilities using LLaMA models.  Technical Details​  Model: Hermes-3-Llama-3.1-8B (8-bit quantized)Source: Hugging Face (NousResearch/Hermes-3-Llama-3.1-8B-GGUF)Context Size: 8192 tokensInference: CPU and GPU (CUDA) support  Features​  Text Generation Completion-style inferenceTemperature controlStop token configurationFrequency and presence penaltiesMaximum token limit control Model Management Automatic model downloadingModel file verificationAutomatic retry on initialization failuresGPU detection for acceleration Performance Message queuing systemCUDA acceleration when availableConfigurable context size

searchDocs.title: Common Issues​
searchDocs.content: Model Initialization Failures  Error: Model initialization failed   Verify model file exists and is not corruptedCheck available system memoryEnsure CUDA is properly configured (if using GPU)  Performance Issues  Warning: No CUDA detected - local response will be slow   Verify CUDA installation if using GPUCheck system resourcesConsider reducing context size

searchDocs.title: Debug Mode​
searchDocs.content: Enable debug logging for detailed troubleshooting:  process.env.DEBUG = 'eliza:plugin-llama:*';

searchDocs.title: System Requirements​
searchDocs.content: Node.js 16.x or higherMinimum 8GB RAM recommendedCUDA-compatible GPU (optional, for acceleration)Sufficient storage for model files

searchDocs.title: Performance Optimization​
searchDocs.content: Model Selection Choose appropriate model sizeUse quantized versions when possibleBalance quality vs speed Resource Management Monitor memory usageConfigure appropriate context sizeOptimize batch processing GPU Utilization Enable CUDA when availableMonitor GPU memoryBalance CPU/GPU workload

searchDocs.title: Support​
searchDocs.content: For issues and feature requests, please:  Check the troubleshooting guide aboveReview existing GitHub issuesSubmit a new issue with: System informationError logsSteps to reproduce

searchDocs.title: Credits​
searchDocs.content: This plugin integrates with and builds upon:  LLaMA - Base language modelnode-llama-cpp - Node.js bindingsGGUF - Model format  Special thanks to:  The LLaMA community for model developmentThe Node.js community for tooling supportThe Eliza community for testing and feedback

Agent: "Successfully market order BTC with 1000 pay and 10 leverage, Transaction: 0x104af5d1a786a2e1a4721a721b2cfccc7e15fa41eec15a489ba1768790adb523"

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Support for multiple intimate hardware devices through Buttplug.io protocolAutomatic device discovery and connection managementBattery level monitoring for supported devicesVibration and rotation control (device-dependent)Graceful connection handling and cleanupBuilt-in device simulation for testingSupport for customizable vibration patternsAutomatic Intiface Engine management

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install @elizaos/plugin-intiface

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: The plugin can be configured through environment variables or runtime settings:  INTIFACE_URL=ws://localhost:12345 INTIFACE_NAME=Eliza Intiface Client DEVICE_NAME=Lovense Nora

searchDocs.title: Basic Device Control​
searchDocs.content: import { intifacePlugin } from '@elizaos/plugin-intiface'; // Vibrate device const result = await eliza.execute({ action: 'VIBRATE', content: { strength: 0.5, // 0.0 to 1.0 duration: 1000, // milliseconds }, }); // Check battery level const battery = await eliza.execute({ action: 'BATTERY', content: {}, });

searchDocs.title: Advanced Features​
searchDocs.content: // Rotation control (for supported devices) const result = await eliza.execute({ action: 'ROTATE', content: { strength: 0.7, duration: 2000, }, });

searchDocs.title: Device Support​
searchDocs.content: The plugin supports various devices through the Buttplug protocol, including but not limited to:  Lovense devices (Nora, Max, etc.)WeVibe productsKiiroo devicesMagic Motion productsAnd many others supported by Buttplug.io

searchDocs.title: Testing​
searchDocs.content: The plugin includes a simulation mode for testing without physical hardware:  bun test-via-bun

searchDocs.title: Dependencies​
searchDocs.content: Buttplug.io (v3.2.2)Intiface EngineWebSocket support

searchDocs.title: Common Issues​
searchDocs.content: Connection Problems Verify Intiface Engine is running (ws://localhost:12345 by default)Check device Bluetooth is enabled and in pairing modeEnsure device is charged and within rangeTry restarting both device and Intiface Engine Device Not Found Confirm device is supported by Buttplug.ioTry manual device pairing through Intiface Central firstCheck if device requires specific firmware versionVerify device is not connected to another application Command Failures Check battery level is sufficientEnsure device is within supported range for command valuesVerify device supports the specific command (vibrate/rotate)Monitor Intiface Engine logs for detailed error messages Performance Issues Reduce command frequency if experiencing lagCheck for Bluetooth interferenceMonitor system resources for potential bottlenecksConsider using wired connection if available

searchDocs.title: Security Best Practices​
searchDocs.content: Device Privacy Use secure WebSocket connections (wss://) when possibleDon't expose Intiface Engine to public networksRegularly check for and apply firmware updatesMonitor device connection status Data Protection Clear device pairing history when neededDon't store sensitive device informationUse unique device names for identificationImplement timeouts for idle connections Access Control Limit device control to authenticated usersImplement command rate limitingUse device-specific permissions where applicableMonitor and log unusual command patterns Network Security Keep Intiface Engine behind firewallUse local connections when possibleImplement connection timeoutsRegular security audits of configurations

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: Through IQ6900's new inscription standard "Code-In", powerful inscription functionality is provided to Eliza. Engrave Eliza on the blockchain forever. All your Character JSON files are input onto the blockchain without compression. Everyone can read your agent from blocks forever.

searchDocs.title: inscription​
searchDocs.content: Code-in your eliza: Go to the site and engrave your character file on-chain. https://elizacodein.com/

searchDocs.title: Onchain git​
searchDocs.content: Commit your update: Update your files anytime. On our site, your files are managed in a format similar to GitHub, and our plugin automatically loads your latest agent file.

searchDocs.title: Let's get started​
searchDocs.content: Edit your .env: write down IQ_WALLET_ADDRESS to your wallet address that you used on website. To be sure, right after inscription, wait about 5 minutes and just type pmpn start. You are now all set.  You have engraved an eternal record. Imagine, someone could develop your agent 200 years from now.  Many things will be updated.  Learn more: https://iq6900.gitbook.io/iq6900/eliza-code-in

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: This plugin integrates Irys functionality into ElizaOS, allowing agents to store and retrieve data in a decentralized manner. It provides a service for creating a decentralized knowledge base and enabling multi-agent collaboration.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: To install this plugin, run the following command:  bun add @elizaos/plugin-irys

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Decentralized Data Storage: Store data permanently on the Irys networkData Retrieval: Fetch stored data using GraphQL queriesMulti-Agent Support: Enable data sharing and collaboration between agentsEthereum Integration: Built-in support for Ethereum wallet authentication

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: The plugin requires the following environment variables:  EVM_WALLET_PRIVATE_KEY: Your EVM wallet private keyAGENTS_WALLET_PUBLIC_KEYS: The public keys of the agents that will be used to retrieve the data (string separated by commas)  For this plugin to work, you need to have an EVM (Base network) wallet with a private key and public address. To prevent any security issues, we recommend using a dedicated wallet for this plugin.  Important: The wallet address needs to have Base Sepolia ETH tokens to store images/files and any data larger than 100KB.

searchDocs.title: How it works​
searchDocs.content: The system consists of three main components that work together to enable decentralized multi-agent operations:

searchDocs.title: 1. Providers​
searchDocs.content: Providers are the data management layer of the system. They:  Interact with the Orchestrator to store dataAggregate information from multiple sources to enhance contextSupport agents with enriched data for better decision-making

searchDocs.title: 2. Orchestrators​
searchDocs.content: Orchestrators manage the flow of communication and requests. They:  Interact with the Irys datachain to store and retrieve dataImplement a tagging system for request categorizationValidate data integrity and authenticityCoordinate the overall system workflow

searchDocs.title: 3. Workers​
searchDocs.content: Workers are specialized agents that execute specific tasks. They:  Perform autonomous operations (e.g., social media interactions, DeFi operations)Interact with Orchestrators to get contextual data from ProvidersInteract with Orchestrators to store execution results on the Irys datachainMaintain transparency by documenting all actions  This architecture ensures a robust, transparent, and efficient system where:  Data is securely stored and verified on the blockchainRequests are properly routed and managedOperations are executed autonomouslyAll actions are traceable and accountable  You can find more information about the system in the A Decentralized Framework for Multi-Agent Systems Using Datachain Technology paper.

searchDocs.title: Worker​
searchDocs.content: As a worker, you can store data on the Irys network using the workerUploadDataOnIrys function. You can use this function to store data from any source to document your actions. You can also use this function to store a request to get data from the Orchestrator to enhance your context.  const { IrysService } = require('@elizaos/plugin-irys'); const irysService: IrysService = runtime.getService(ServiceType.IRYS); const data = 'Provide Liquidity to the ETH pool on Stargate'; const result = await irysService.workerUploadDataOnIrys( data, IrysDataType.OTHER, IrysMessageType.DATA_STORAGE, ['DeFi'], ['Stargate', 'LayerZero'] ); console.log(`Data uploaded successfully at the following url: ${result.url}`);   To upload files or images :  const { IrysService } = require('@elizaos/plugin-irys'); const irysService: IrysService = runtime.getService(ServiceType.IRYS); const userAttachmentToStore = state.recentMessagesData[1].content.attachments[0].url.replace( 'agent\\agent', 'agent' ); const result = await irysService.workerUploadDataOnIrys( userAttachmentToStore, IrysDataType.IMAGE, IrysMessageType.DATA_STORAGE, ['Social Media'], ['X', 'Twitter'] ); console.log(`Data uploaded successfully at the following url: ${result.url}`);   To store a request to get data from the Orchestrator to enhance your context, you can use the workerUploadDataOnIrys function with the IrysMessageType.REQUEST message type.  const { IrysService } = require('@elizaos/plugin-irys'); const irysService: IrysService = runtime.getService(ServiceType.IRYS); const data = 'Which Pool farm has the highest APY on Stargate?'; const result = await irysService.workerUploadDataOnIrys( data, IrysDataType.OTHER, IrysMessageType.REQUEST, ['DeFi'], ['Stargate', 'LayerZero'], [0.5], // Validation Threshold - Not implemented yet [1], // Minimum Providers [false], // Test Provider - Not implemented yet [0.5] // Reputation - Not implemented yet ); console.log(`Data uploaded successfully at the following url: ${result.url}`); console.log(`Response from the Orchestrator: ${result.data}`);

searchDocs.title: Provider​
searchDocs.content: As a provider, you can store data on the Irys network using the providerUploadDataOnIrys function. The data you provide can be retrieved by the Orchestrator to enhance the context of the Worker.  const { IrysService } = require('@elizaos/plugin-irys'); const irysService: IrysService = runtime.getService(ServiceType.IRYS); const data = 'ETH Pool Farm APY : 6,86%'; const result = await irysService.providerUploadDataOnIrys( data, IrysDataType.OTHER, ['DeFi'], ['Stargate', 'LayerZero'] ); console.log(`Data uploaded successfully at the following url: ${result.url}`);   To upload files or images :  const { IrysService } = require('@elizaos/plugin-irys'); const irysService: IrysService = runtime.getService(ServiceType.IRYS); const userAttachmentToStore = state.recentMessagesData[1].content.attachments[0].url.replace( 'agent\\agent', 'agent' ); const result = await irysService.providerUploadDataOnIrys( userAttachmentToStore, IrysDataType.IMAGE, ['Social Media'], ['X', 'Twitter'] ); console.log(`Data uploaded successfully at the following url: ${result.url}`);

searchDocs.title: Retrieving Data​
searchDocs.content: To retrieve data from the Irys network, you can use the getDataFromAnAgent function. This function will retrieve all data associated with the given wallet addresses, tags and timestamp. The function automatically detects the content type and returns either JSON data or file/image URLs accordingly.  For files and images: Returns the URL of the stored contentFor other data types: Returns a JSON object with the following structure:  { data: string, // The stored data address: string // The address of the agent that stored the data }   By using only the provider address you want to retrieve data from :  const { IrysService } = require('@elizaos/plugin-irys'); const irysService = runtime.getService(ServiceType.IRYS); const agentsWalletPublicKeys = runtime.getSetting('AGENTS_WALLET_PUBLIC_KEYS').split(','); const data = await irysService.getDataFromAnAgent(agentsWalletPublicKeys); console.log(`Data retrieved successfully. Data: ${data}`);   By using tags and timestamp:  const { IrysService } = require('@elizaos/plugin-irys'); const irysService = runtime.getService(ServiceType.IRYS); const tags = [ { name: 'Message-Type', values: [IrysMessageType.DATA_STORAGE] }, { name: 'Service-Category', values: ['DeFi'] }, { name: 'Protocol', values: ['Stargate', 'LayerZero'] }, ]; const timestamp = { from: 1710000000, to: 1710000000 }; const data = await irysService.getDataFromAnAgent(null, tags, timestamp); console.log(`Data retrieved successfully. Data: ${data}`);   If everything is null, the function will retrieve all data from the Irys network.

searchDocs.title: About Irys​
searchDocs.content: Irys is the first Layer 1 (L1) programmable datachain designed to optimize both data storage and execution. By integrating storage and execution, Irys enhances the utility of blockspace, enabling a broader spectrum of web services to operate on-chain.

searchDocs.title: Key Features of Irys​
searchDocs.content: Unified Platform: Combines data storage and execution, allowing developers to eliminate dependencies and integrate efficient on-chain data seamlessly.Cost-Effective Storage: Optimized specifically for data storage, making it significantly cheaper to store data on-chain compared to traditional blockchains.Programmable Datachain: The IrysVM can utilize on-chain data during computations, enabling dynamic and real-time applications.Decentralization: Designed to minimize centralization risks by distributing control.Free Storage for Small Data: Storing less than 100KB of data is free.GraphQL Querying: Metadata stored on Irys can be queried using GraphQL.

searchDocs.title: GraphQL Query Examples​
searchDocs.content: The plugin uses GraphQL to retrieve transaction metadata. Here's an example query structure:  const QUERY = gql` query ($owners: [String!], $tags: [TagFilter!], $timestamp: TimestampFilter) { transactions(owners: $owners, tags: $tags, timestamp: $timestamp) { edges { node { id address } } } } `; const variables = { owners: owners, tags: tags, timestamp: timestamp, }; const data: TransactionGQL = await graphQLClient.request(QUERY, variables);

searchDocs.title: IrysService​
searchDocs.content: The main service provided by this plugin implements the following interface:  interface UploadIrysResult { success: boolean; url?: string; error?: string; data?: any; } interface DataIrysFetchedFromGQL { success: boolean; data: any; error?: string; } interface GraphQLTag { name: string; values: any[]; } const enum IrysMessageType { REQUEST = 'REQUEST', DATA_STORAGE = 'DATA_STORAGE', REQUEST_RESPONSE = 'REQUEST_RESPONSE', } const enum IrysDataType { FILE = 'FILE', IMAGE = 'IMAGE', OTHER = 'OTHER', } interface IrysTimestamp { from: number; to: number; } interface IIrysService extends Service { getDataFromAnAgent( agentsWalletPublicKeys: string[], tags: GraphQLTag[], timestamp: IrysTimestamp ): Promise<DataIrysFetchedFromGQL>; workerUploadDataOnIrys( data: any, dataType: IrysDataType, messageType: IrysMessageType, serviceCategory: string[], protocol: string[], validationThreshold: number[], minimumProviders: number[], testProvider: boolean[], reputation: number[] ): Promise<UploadIrysResult>; providerUploadDataOnIrys( data: any, dataType: IrysDataType, serviceCategory: string[], protocol: string[] ): Promise<UploadIrysResult>; }   Methods​  getDataFromAnAgent(agentsWalletPublicKeys: string[], tags: GraphQLTag[], timestamp: IrysTimestamp): Retrieves all data associated with the given parametersworkerUploadDataOnIrys(data: any, dataType: IrysDataType, messageType: IrysMessageType, serviceCategory: string[], protocol: string[], validationThreshold: number[], minimumProviders: number[], testProvider: boolean[], reputation: number[]): Uploads data to Irys and returns the orchestrator response (request or data storage)providerUploadDataOnIrys(data: any, dataType: IrysDataType, serviceCategory: string[], protocol: string[]): Uploads data to Irys and returns orchestrator response (data storage)

searchDocs.title: Overview​
searchDocs.content: This plugin connects your Eliza agent to Messari's comprehensive AI-powered APIs, enabling sophisticated crypto research and market analysis capabilities. It intelligently detects and processes research questions from conversations, leveraging Messari's proprietary data and expertise.

searchDocs.title: Demo​
searchDocs.content: https://github.com/messari/plugin-messari-ai-toolkit/blob/master/.github/assets/eliza-tutorial.mp4

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: Seamless integration with Messari's AI-Toolkit /chat/completions APIIntelligent detection of crypto-related research questionsReal-time market data and asset metrics analysisAccess to consolidated news summarizationsAsset due diligence insightsFundraising and investment data visualization capabilities

searchDocs.title: Setup​
searchDocs.content: First, clone either: The main Eliza repository: github.com/elizaOS/elizaOR the Eliza starter repository: github.com/elizaOS/eliza-starter Install dependencies and build the project: bun install bun build

searchDocs.title: Installing the Messari Plugin​
searchDocs.content: Depending on which repository you cloned, use one of the following commands:  For Main Eliza Repository:  bun --filter agent add github:messari/plugin-messari-ai-toolkit   For Eliza Starter:  bun add github:messari/plugin-messari-ai-toolkit   Note: For the latest plugin mappings and compatibility information, refer to the eliza-plugins registry.  to use, import into agent/index.ts and add as a plugin

searchDocs.title: Configuration​
searchDocs.content: To use this plugin, you'll need a Messari API key. The Messari AI Toolkit is an enterprise product that requires:  An Enterprise (ENT) subscriptionPurchase of the AI Toolkit service package + creditsAPI key generation

searchDocs.title: Enterprise Access​
searchDocs.content: The AI Toolkit subscription includes access to Messari's base package:  Asset APINews APIMarketdata API

searchDocs.title: Getting an API Key​
searchDocs.content: Subscribe to Messari EnterprisePurchase the AI Toolkit packageVisit Messari Account Settings to generate your API keyUse the API key in your configuration

searchDocs.title: API Endpoints​
searchDocs.content: The Toolkit endpoints are accessible at api.messari.io/ai. For detailed API documentation, visit the Messari Developer Docs.

searchDocs.title: Usage​
searchDocs.content: Import and register the plugin with your Eliza agentConfigure your API keyStart asking crypto-related questions!  The plugin will automatically detect relevant research questions and query Messari's AI Toolkit for comprehensive answers.

searchDocs.title: About Messari AI Toolkit​
searchDocs.content: Messari's AI Toolkit is an enterprise-grade suite of AI-powered APIs designed specifically for the crypto ecosystem. It provides:  Crypto-aware completions endpoint (OpenAI-compatible)Asset extraction on arbitrary documentsDirect access to underlying agentsNews recaps and summarizationsDeep understanding of crypto-specific terminology and contextReal-time market data analysis

searchDocs.title: Use Cases​
searchDocs.content: Market trend analysis with real-time dataAutomated crypto research and report generationNews summarization across multiple sourcesAsset due diligence with Enterprise Diligence ReportsFundraising and investment data visualizationAsset extraction and classification for document contextualization

searchDocs.title: Security​
searchDocs.content: This plugin requires secure handling of Messari API keys. Never expose your API key in your code or version control system.

searchDocs.title: Performance Considerations​
searchDocs.content: The plugin may introduce additional latency due to API calls. Consider implementing appropriate caching and error handling strategies in production environments.

searchDocs.content: Contributions are welcome! Please feel free to submit a Pull Request.

searchDocs.content: MIT

searchDocs.title: Support​
searchDocs.content: For questions about API access and testing, contact bijan.massoumi@messari.io.  For technical support with the plugin, please open an issue in the repository.

searchDocs.title: Description​
searchDocs.content: LetzAI is an image generation platform and visual discovery engine. It enables anyone to generate images about anything, by allowing users to add themselves, their products or their art style to the platform as AI Models.  This plugin integrates LetzAI with Eliza, enabling agents to generate images using any LetzAI Models, including the ones you may have created specifically of or for your agent.  To use this plugin, you will need a LetzAI API Key, which can be created on your subscription page here. A subscription is required to create an API key.  To generate images the plugin introduces its own GENERATE_IMAGE action.  The plugin was not tested together with other image generation functionalities.

searchDocs.title: Installation​
searchDocs.content: bun install @elizaos/plugin-letzai

searchDocs.title: Environment Variables​
searchDocs.content: LETZAI_API_LEY=<Your LetzAI API Key> LETZAI_MODELS="@hailee, @examplemodel2"   Inside the plugin's index.tsx file is a "improvePrompt" variable and some code that is commented out. This code could be enhanced to make the instructions from chat be passed to the API in a better way. This is an open TO DO.

searchDocs.content: Clone the repositoryInstall dependencies:  bun install   Build the plugin:  bun run build

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: I am currently working on an example Agent called "HaileeAgent". Will share more information on this as I progress.

searchDocs.title: Other Notes​
searchDocs.content: In my own character.json file for Hailee, I have integrated the plugin like this:   "plugins": ["../../packages/plugin-letzai/src/index.ts"], "actions": ["GENERATE_IMAGE"],   But I'm not sure yet this is the correct way for public repos.
